ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course has been a rigorous examination of the history of sexuality from the perspective of intellectual and cultural history. The multi-disciplinary approach the course took (from French, WGSS, and History) made it very challenging but also rewarding: I got to think about the topic in many different ways.

How to read a book how to really read it. At the end of each seminar we ended in a place very different from the text. We were questioned about the author's biases and oversights, what the text doesn't say. It's made me rethink the way I read.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course's greatest strength (a mix of perspectives) is also what I found the most challenging (and at times disorienting) with it: the mix of backgrounds and disciplines of both the students and the readings.

Sometimes it was clear that people were coming from different backgrounds with the subject matter. I thought that this made for a really interesting discussion, and that this was ultimately worked through.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
